trial_identification.studytitle: Safety Study of Home Oxygen Therapy for Children With Acute Bronchiolitis
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Randomised Controlled Trial: Home Oxygen Therapy Versus Hospital Oxygen Therapy for Children With Acute Bronchiolitis

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other inflammatory or immune system disorders

Treatment: surgery - Home oxygen therapy
Experimental: 1 - Children discharged home with oxygen
No Intervention: 2 - Children remain in hospital for oxygen therapy
Treatment: surgery: Home oxygen therapy Administer oxygen at home or in hospital

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
1. 3 - 24 months of age (corrected gestation)
2. Clinical diagnosis of acute bronchiolitis
3. Adequate feeding (>50% normal) & hydration
4. O2 saturation >92% on <1litre/minute nasal cannula oxygen.
5. Observed and clinically stable for at least 24 hours in hospital
6. Pass modified "safety in air test "
7. Caregivers must be counseled about risk of smoking around a child receiving oxygen supplementation
8. Caregivers must be adequately educated about home oxygen
9. HiTH nurses able to visit at home at least twice daily, in addition to daily phone call
10. Paediatrician agrees that child is eligible for recruitment in study
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
1. Pre-existing cardiac, pulmonary (including chronic lung disease of infancy, cystic fibrosis and congenital or acquired airway anomalies), and neuromuscular disorders
2. History of apnea
3. Prematurity <34 weeks gestation

recruitment.hospital: Princess Margaret Hospital for Children - Perth

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Home oxygen therapy is considered an appropriate and relatively safe option for children with chronic respiratory problems such as chronic lung disease of prematurity, but the use of home oxygen therapy for children with acute respiratory problems is limited. With the recent establishment of a "Hospital in The Home" (HiTH) program at our institution, we sought to determine the safety, parental satisfaction and economic advantage of home oxygen therapy for children with acute bronchiolitis compared with traditional inpatient hospitalization.
